data.title: All 55 Joanne Woodward Movies (in Order)
data.text:
Get ready for an unforgettable cinematic journey as we explore the illustrious career of Joanne Woodward, a Hollywood legend! From her breakout roles in the 1950s to her powerful performances in the 21st century, Woodward‚Äôs diverse and captivating filmography will undoubtedly leave you amazed. So sit back, relax, and get ready to delve into the world of Joanne Woodward Movies!

As an Amazon‚Ñ¢ Associate, we earn from qualifying purchases.

1. Count Three and Pray (1955)

In the post-Civil War era, the small, Southern town of Cedar Creek becomes the unlikely new home to a mysterious pastor, Reverend David Lanning (Van Heflin). With a questionable past, Lanning‚Äôs arrival causes a stir among the townspeople, particularly when he befriends a young, na√Øve woman named Susan Meredith (Joanne Woodward).

üì∫ Watch now free with Prime

üñºÔ∏è Check out these cool movie posters & art

2. A Kiss Before Dying (1956)

A Kiss Before Dying, directed by Gerd Oswald and written by Lawrence Roman and Ira Levin, is a gripping 1956 crime drama that tells the chilling tale of Bud Corliss, a ruthless college student determined to marry an heiress. As the plot unfolds, it becomes clear that Bud is willing to resort to murder in his quest to claim the Kingship family‚Äôs mining fortune. With a runtime of just over an hour, this film noir mystery stars Robert Wagner, Jeffrey Hunter, and Virginia Leith in unforgettable roles that will keep you on the edge of your seat.

üì∫ Watch now free with Prime

üñºÔ∏è Check out these cool movie posters & art

3. No Down Payment (1957)

In the sleepy suburbs of California, where young couples dream of the perfect life, ‚ÄúNo Down Payment‚Äù unravels the complexities of four marriages. The American Dream starts to crumble as these couples face alcoholism, racism, promiscuity, and discrimination against lack of education.

üì∫ Watch now free with Prime

üñºÔ∏è Check out these cool movie posters & art

4. The Three Faces of Eve (1957)

Experience the heart-wrenching journey of a woman suffering from Multiple Personality Disorder as she navigates the labyrinth of her own mind in ‚ÄúThe Three Faces of Eve. ‚Äù This suspenseful drama, directed by Nunnally Johnson and starring Joanne Woodward, unfolds as a psychiatrist, played by Lee J. Cobb, attempts to unravel the complexities of this disorder.

üì∫ Watch now free with Prime

üñºÔ∏è Check out these cool movie posters & art

5. Rally ‚ÄòRound the Flag, Boys! (1958)

Rally ‚ÄòRound the Flag, Boys! ‚Äù is a 1958 comedy film directed by Leo McCarey, featuring a star-studded cast including Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward. Set in the quaint town of Putnam‚Äôs Landing, the movie explores the reactions of its citizens to the construction of an Army missile base in their backyard.

üì∫ Watch now free with Prime

üñºÔ∏è Check out these cool movie posters & art

6. The Long, Hot Summer (1958)

Experience the heat and passion of William Faulkner‚Äôs unforgettable novel, ‚ÄúThe Long, Hot Summer, ‚Äù in this tantalizing 1958 film adaptation. Set in the sweltering Mississippi sun, the story follows conman and barn burner Ben Quick as he insinuates himself into the affluent Varner family. As the weather heats up, so too does the tension between the Varners - the seductive Eula and her jealous husband Will, eagerly pursue new love interests; the ambitious Jody tries to win over the beautiful Clara, who has her sights set on someone else; and the enigmatic Ben struggles to keep his secrets hidden.

üì∫ Watch now free with Prime

üñºÔ∏è Check out these cool movie posters & art

7. The Sound and the Fury (1959)

The Sound and the Fury‚Äù (1959) is a gripping drama that captures the essence of a Southern aristocratic family grappling with the dissolution of their once-prominent clan. Set during the tumultuous period of Mississippi‚Äôs Southern Reconstruction in the post-American Civil War era, the story delves into the disintegration of faith, fortune, and respect, as the characters struggle to adapt and maintain their social status.

üì∫ Watch now free with Prime

üñºÔ∏è Check out these cool movie posters & art

8. The Fugitive Kind (1960)

The Fugitive Kind‚Äù is a gripping drama set in a small Mississippi town, boasting a captivating ensemble cast led by Marlon Brando, Joanne Woodward, and Anna Magnani. Directed by Sidney Lumet and adapted from a Tennessee Williams screenplay, this riveting film follows Valentine ‚ÄúSnakeskin‚Äù Xavier (Brando), a drifter striving for redemption.

üñºÔ∏è Check out these cool movie posters & art

9. From the Terrace (1960)

From the Terrace, ‚Äù released in 1960, is a gripping drama and romance film starring Paul Newman, Joanne Woodward, and Myrna Loy. The ambitious young executive, played by Paul Newman, finds himself torn between his love for his wife and the allure of a successful Wall Street career.

10. Paris Blues (1961)

In 1961, the highly-anticipated film, ‚ÄòParis Blues‚Äô, hits theaters, and fans of all genres are eagerly awaiting its release. Set in the iconic city of Paris during the 1960s, ‚ÄòParis Blues‚Äô follows the story of two American expatriate jazz musicians who, by chance, fall in love with two American tourist girls. As they explore the vibrant jazz music scene that thrives in Paris, their love stories intertwine, and their paths become forever intertwined.

11. A New Kind of Love (1963)

In the whimsical comedy ‚ÄúA New Kind of Love‚Äù (1963), directed by Melville Shavelson, the glamorous world of Paris‚Äô fashion industry serves as a backdrop for a delightful tale of mistaken identity. The film stars Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward, husband and wife who co-starred in several other films, as Steve Sherman and Samantha Blake.

12. Signpost to Murder (1964)

Signpost to Murder‚Äù (1964), directed by George Englund, is a riveting crime, mystery, and thriller film that keeps viewers on the edge of their seats. The plot revolves around a woman who finds an escapee from an asylum in her home, and as the story unfolds, she is revealed to have her own dark secrets.

13. A Big Hand for the Little Lady (1966)

A Big Hand for the Little Lady‚Äù is a delightful 1966 comedy-western film directed by Fielder Cook, with a runtime of 1 hour and 35 minutes. The movie stars Henry Fonda, Joanne Woodward, and Jason Robards and is produced by Eden Productions Inc.

14. A Fine Madness (1966)

A Fine Madness (1966) follows the story of Samson Shillitoe, a poet with a penchant for women and a talent for causing chaos. His irresistible charm and wit take center stage in this captivating tale that showcases his struggle to find inspiration amid his battles with writer‚Äôs block.

15. Rachel, Rachel (1968)

Rachel, Rachel‚Äù is a classic 1968 drama directed by Paul Newman and written by Stewart Stern and Margaret Laurence. The film follows a young school teacher named Rachel who leads a lonely life with her mother. When a man from the city invites her out on a date, Rachel starts questioning her future and the direction of her life. The movie explores complex themes such as friendship between women, lesbian subtext, and the struggle to find one‚Äôs place in the world.

16. King: A Filmed Record‚Ä¶ Montgomery to Memphis (1969)

King: A Filmed Record. . Montgomery to Memphis‚Äù (1969) is a powerful documentary that chronicles the life and civil rights activism of Martin Luther King Jr. The film, which runs for 3 hours and 5 minutes, spans across decades, capturing King‚Äôs transformative journey from Montgomery, Alabama in 1956, through Tennessee, and finally reaching Memphis, Tennessee in 1968.

üñºÔ∏è Check out these cool movie posters & art

17. Winning (1969)

Winning‚Äù is a gripping drama that showcases the intense world of motor sports racing. The story follows Frank Capua, a promising race engineer, who daringly aspires to conquer the prestigious Indianapolis 500.

18. WUSA (1970)

WUSA‚Äù is a drama film set in the Deep South, where a local radio station becomes the epicenter of a right-wing conspiracy. Directed by Stuart Rosenberg and written by Robert Stone, the movie stars Paul Newman, Joanne Woodward, and Anthony Perkins.

üì∫ Watch now free with Prime

üñºÔ∏è Check out these cool movie posters & art

19. All the Way Home (1971)

In ‚ÄúAll the Way Home‚Äù (1971), Mary Follet finds herself dealing with the harsh realities of life after her husband is tragically killed in a car accident. With a young son and a baby on the way, Mary is left to face her struggles alone.

üì∫ Watch now free with Prime

20. They Might Be Giants (1971)

They Might Be Giants, a 1971 film directed by Anthony Harvey, is a delightful mix of comedy, mystery, and romance, that takes place within the confines of a Manhattan psychiatric hospital. The story follows a man who vehemently believes that he is none other than Sherlock Holmes.

21. The Effect of Gamma Rays on Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds (1972)

The Effect of Gamma Rays on Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds‚Äù is a captivating 1972 drama film, which initially premiered in 1973. Directed by Paul Newman and written by the talented duo of Paul Zindel and Alvin Sargent, the film stars an ensemble cast that includes Joanne Woodward, Nell Potts, and Roberta Wallach. Set in the picturesque backdrop of Connecticut, the story revolves around the life of a middle-aged woman who grapples with raising her two daughters. The older daughter basks in the limelight while the younger one nurtures her passion for science.

22. The Drowning Pool (1975)

The Drowning Pool‚Äù is a compelling crime drama that takes viewers on a tumultuous journey through the streets of 1975 New Orleans, Louisiana. Starring iconic actors Paul Newman, Joanne Woodward, and Anthony Franciosa, this gripping tale follows the life of a hard-boiled, no-nonsense private investigator, Harper.

23. Come Back, Little Sheba (1977)

Come Back, Little Sheba is a gripping drama directed by Silvio Narizzano that explores the complex dynamics of a couple‚Äôs relationship. The 1977 film stars iconic actors Laurence Olivier and Joanne Woodward as a recovering alcoholic husband and his unassuming wife, who are faced with an emotional crisis when they host an alluring lodger. The film delves into the challenges faced by the couple, ultimately examining the intricacies of a dysfunctional marriage and the complications of a unexpected love triangle.

24. A Christmas to Remember (1978)

A Christmas to Remember‚Äù is a heartwarming drama that follows the story of a city-bred grandson as he embarks on a journey to his grandparents‚Äô farm during the Great Depression. Unfamiliar with rural life, he must grow up under the strict care of his grandparents. As the holiday season arrives, the grandson finds himself helping his grandfather deliver a surprise gift to their community church with the assistance of a mysterious phantom stranger.

25. The End (1978)

The End, ‚Äù a 1978 film starring Burt Reynolds, takes us on a hilariously dark journey filled with comedy and drama. In a world of attempted suicide and terminal illness, Reynolds‚Äô character finds himself on the brink of his final moments. With a bungled job at suicide, he sets out on an outrageous quest for redemption.

26. See How She Runs (1978)

See How She Runs‚Äù is a powerful 1978 drama film that tells the extraordinary story of a 40-year-old divorced teacher who suddenly changes her life by deciding to join the Boston Marathon. This compelling tale, directed by Richard T. Heffron, showcases the transformation of a woman who faces her fears, finds renewed hope, and forges a strong, unbreakable bond with her daughter.

27. Good Old Days Part II (1978)

Step back in time and relive the golden era of rock and roll with ‚ÄòGood Old Days Part II‚Äô. Set in a bustling nightclub, this 2-hour musical journey takes you through the early years of rock and roll. Enjoy candid conversations and nostalgic film clips, all while being entertained by memorable performances from the legends of the time.

28. The Shadow Box (1980)

The Shadow Box is a deeply moving drama that unfolds in the grounds of a hospital where three terminally ill cancer patients dwell in separate cottages, attended by their loved ones. As they navigate their final days, the patients come to terms with their past and present, while their families and friends try to maintain hope and strength in the face of their imminent loss.

üì∫ Watch now free with Prime

üñºÔ∏è Check out these cool movie posters & art

29. Crisis at Central High (1981)

Crisis at Central High (1981) is a powerful drama that explores the tumultuous and vital period in American history when federally-ordered integration was implemented in Central High School in Little Rock, Arkansas in 1957. This extraordinary event was met with fierce resistance from the white community, who believed that their children should not be forced to attend school with African Americans. Directed by Lamont Johnson and written by Elizabeth Huckaby, Richard Levinson, and William Link, this engaging film delves deep into the heart of the civil rights struggle, with masterful performances by Joanne Woodward, Charles Durning, and Henderson Forsythe.

üì∫ Watch now free with Prime

üñºÔ∏è Check out these cool movie posters & art

30. Candida (1983)

Experience the timeless drama of ‚ÄúCandida, ‚Äù a story that transports viewers to 19th-century England. Candida, portrayed by Joanne Woodward, is the devoted and beloved wife of the famous clergyman, Reverend James Mavor Morell, played by Ronald Bishop.

üì∫ Watch now free with Prime

üñºÔ∏è Check out these cool movie posters & art

31. Harry & Son (1984)

Harry & Son‚Äù is a moving drama film released in 1984, helmed by esteemed actor and director, Paul Newman. Set in a demolition-filled world, we follow the life of Harry Keach, a widower and crane operator on a demolition crew, who‚Äôs been shouldering the burden of grief for two years.

32. Do You Remember Love (1985)

Do You Remember Love‚Äù is a poignant drama that delves into the heartbreaking world of Alzheimer‚Äôs disease. When English professor Barbara Wyatt-Hollis begins to experience the devastating effects of the disease, her life and that of her family dramatically change.

33. The Spencer Tracy Legacy: A Tribute by Katharine Hepburn (1986)

The Spencer Tracy Legacy: A Tribute by Katharine Hepburn is a heartwarming 1986 documentary that delves into the unparalleled on-screen and off-screen dynamic of one of Hollywood‚Äôs most iconic and celebrated couples - Spencer Tracy and Katharine Hepburn. Delivering an immersive journey through their extraordinary life together, the film stands as a testament to the enduring legacy of their love and shared cinematic experiences. Directed by David Heeley and written by John Miller, this 1h 27min documentary features an all-star lineup, including Joan Bennett, Angela Lansbury, Joan Fontaine, and the incomparable Katharine Hepburn herself.

üñºÔ∏è Check out these cool movie posters & art

34. The Glass Menagerie (1987)

The Glass Menagerie, a heart-wrenching drama directed by Tony Award-winner Paul Newman and written by the renowned Tennessee Williams, transports viewers into the world of Tom Wingfield. The film, initially released in 1987, delves into the depths of a family‚Äôs struggles and the dreams of its members.

35. Mr. & Mrs. Bridge (1990)

Mr. & Mrs. Bridge‚Äù is a captivating drama set during World War II that explores the disintegration of an upper-class family due to the contrasting values of its patriarch and his children. Directed by James Ivory and written by Evan S. Connell and Ruth Prawer Jhabvala, the film stars Paul Newman, Joanne Woodward, and Saundra McClain.

36. Philadelphia (1993)

Philadelphia‚Äù is a deeply moving and thought-provoking drama that explores the complex relationships between love, loss, and acceptance. Set in the early ‚Äô90s, the film follows the life of Andrew Beckett, a dedicated attorney diagnosed with HIV, who faces discrimination and unfounded accusations when he is unjustly fired by his prestigious law firm. With nowhere else to turn, he enlists the help of a homophobic small-time lawyer, Joe Miller, who reluctantly takes on the wrongful dismissal lawsuit.

üì∫ Watch now free with Prime

üñºÔ∏è Check out these cool movie posters & art

37. Edward R. Murrow: The Best of ‚ÄòPerson to Person‚Äô (1993)

Edward R. Murrow: The Best of ‚ÄòPerson to Person‚Äô‚Äù, a riveting documentary film from 1993, sheds light on the extraordinary life and career of the legendary American journalist, Edward R. Murrow.

38. Foreign Affairs (1993)

Foreign Affairs‚Äù is a delightful romantic comedy set in London where two couples discover love and companionship amidst their personal struggles. A heartwarming blend of comedy and romance, the film offers a poignant portrayal of loneliness, self-discovery, and the transformative power of love.

39. Blind Spot (1993)

Blind Spot, released in 1993, is a compelling drama that explores the complex journey of a couple, played by Joanne Woodward and Reed Diamond, and their troubled daughter Laura Linney, suffering from cocaine addiction. Directed by Michael Toshiyuki Uno, the film‚Äôs brilliant storytelling is further enhanced by its talented team of writers, including Michael McTaggart, Ellen M. Violett, and Nina Shengold.

40. The Age of Innocence (1993)

The Age of Innocence‚Äù is a captivating 1993 romantic drama film directed by Martin Scorsese, based on the novel by Edith Wharton. The movie transports viewers to the world of high society in 19th century New York, where wealthy lawyer Newland Archer falls deeply in love with Ellen Olenska, a woman separated from her husband. However, Archer‚Äôs love is complicated by his engagement to the woman‚Äôs cousin, May.

41. Breathing Lessons (1994)

Breathing Lessons, ‚Äù a heartwarming drama released in 1994, follows the story of a married couple, Norman and Irene Quayle, as they embark on a journey to their friend‚Äôs funeral. As they drive, Norman and Irene reminisce about their lives and their love for each other, prompting them to reevaluate their relationship. The movie, starring James Garner and Joanne Woodward, explores the themes of a life review, reconciliation, and renewed love, set against the backdrop of a reunion.

üñºÔ∏è Check out these cool movie posters & art

42. Golden Anniversary (1995)

Golden Anniversary‚Äù is a fascinating 1995 documentary celebrating the remarkable 50-year marriage of Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip. This commemorative video takes viewers on an intimate journey through the highs and lows of their marriage, exploring their world travels, family milestones, and both happy and sad moments shared over the years.

43. My Knees Were Jumping: Remembering the Kindertransports (1996)

My Knees Were Jumping: Remembering the Kindertransports is a poignant documentary that captures an extraordinary moment in Holocaust history. Directed by Melissa Hacker, this powerful narrative unfolds from the perspective of a survivor‚Äôs daughter, who recounts the story with intimate sensitivity.

üñºÔ∏è Check out these cool movie posters & art

44. Twentieth Century Fox: The First 50 Years (1997)

Twentieth Century Fox: The First 50 Years takes viewers on a captivating journey through the history of one of the world‚Äôs most renowned film studios. Starting with the studio‚Äôs beginnings under the visionary Hungarian immigrant, William Fox, the documentary delves into the evolution of the company as it transformed from a small film distribution business to a major Hollywood player.

üñºÔ∏è Check out these cool movie posters & art

45. Cleopatra: The Film That Changed Hollywood (2001)

Cleopatra: The Film That Changed Hollywood‚Äù is a gripping documentary that delves into the making of this iconic film and offers a fascinating look at the challenges that faced the movie industry as it unfolded. This captivating film explores the idiosyncrasies, difficulties, and intrigues that surrounded the production of the blockbuster. The film takes viewers on an enchanting journey through the making of a film that changed the face of Hollywood forever.

46. Far from Heaven (2002)

In the 1950s, a housewife is trapped in a strained marriage as racial tensions simmer just outside her home. The captivating drama, ‚ÄúFar from Heaven, ‚Äù unfolds against the backdrop of a time when forbidden love and bigotry coexisted.

üì∫ Watch now free with Prime

üñºÔ∏è Check out these cool movie posters & art

47. Our Town (2003)

Our Town‚Äù is a heartfelt drama that transports viewers to Grover‚Äôs Corners, a charming fictional small town where the story unfolds between 1901 and 1913. Academy Award winning director James Naughton brings Thornton Wilder‚Äôs classic play to life, masterfully capturing the essence of everyday life, love, and loss.

üì∫ Watch now free with Prime

üñºÔ∏è Check out these cool movie posters & art

48. James Dean: Forever Young (2005)

James Dean: Forever Young‚Äù is a riveting documentary that delves into the life and career of the enigmatic James Dean, an enduring symbol of youth and rebellion. Narrated by Martin Sheen, the film traces Dean‚Äôs brief but impactful journey, shedding light on his early work in television and his three iconic features. The creators employ a rich collection of archival footage and interviews to bring to life the young man who forever shaped Hollywood and captured the hearts of millions.

üì∫ Watch now free with Prime

49. The Adventures of Errol Flynn (2005)

The Adventures of Errol Flynn‚Äù is a riveting documentary that delves into the life and career of the legendary actor and adventurer, Errol Flynn. Guided by the recollections of Flynn‚Äôs friends and family, this film offers a captivating insight into the life of a man who was not only a cinematic icon but also a real-life hero.

üñºÔ∏è Check out these cool movie posters & art

50. Keepers of Eden (2007)

In the heart of the Amazon Rainforest lies a captivating documentary that showcases the resilience and traditions of the Huarani tribe. ‚ÄúKeepers of Eden‚Äù is a must-watch for anyone fascinated by the environment and preserving its delicate ecosystem. This groundbreaking film explores the tribe‚Äôs lives that have been rooted in the rainforest of Ecuador for thousands of years.

51. Gayby (2012)

Experience a hilarious and heartfelt tale of friendship and parenthood as ‚ÄòGayby‚Äô takes you on a journey with Jenn (straight) and Matt (gay), two college best friends who decide to fulfill a childhood promise to have a child together. In their thirties and still single, they embark on a bumbling quest to conceive the old-fashioned way.

52. Lucky Them (2013)

Lucky Them‚Äù is a quirky, offbeat comedy-drama where rock journalist Ella Swenson (Toni Collette) finds herself entangled in a mystery, as she embarks on a quest to uncover the whereabouts of her estranged ex-boyfriend, Elliot (Thomas Haden Church). As Ella navigates the unfamiliar world of her former lover, she‚Äôs aided by an oddball cast of characters, led by Elliot‚Äôs eccentric sister Annie (Nina Arianda).

53. Gore Vidal: The United States of Amnesia (2013)

Gore Vidal: The United States of Amnesia‚Äù is a captivating documentary film that delves into the life and political views of renowned American author and commentator, Gore Vidal. Directed by Nicholas D. Wrathall, the film explores Vidal‚Äôs perspective on the transformation of America and the rise of the right-wing political establishment.

54. And the Oscar Goes to‚Ä¶ (2014)

And the Oscar Goes to. . ‚Äù - a riveting documentary that delves into the rich history of the Academy Awards. Directed by Rob Epstein and Jeffrey Friedman, the film brings to life the glitz and glamour, the triumphs and tribulations associated with this prestigious event.

üì∫ Watch now free with Prime

55. Winning: The Racing Life of Paul Newman (2015)

Winning: The Racing Life of Paul Newman is a thrilling documentary that offers an unprecedented look into the life of a legendary racing icon. The film, released in 2015 and directed by Adam Carolla and Nate Adams, features the riveting story of Paul Newman‚Äôs thirty-five-year-long car-racing career as both a driver and owner. From his early days behind the wheel to his ultimate ascension to becoming not just a renowned actor but also an accomplished racing hero, this fast-paced film captures the essence of Newman‚Äôs unrelenting spirit and passion for speed.

üì∫ Watch now free with Prime
